frontMatter.title: Embracing the future with the View Transitions API
frontMatter.description: Merchants need tools that are not just powerful, but also intuitive. That's why we're experimenting with new ways to enhance the Shopify admin experience using the View Transitions API.

frontMatter.title: Actions
frontMatter.shortDescription: Perform tasks or take actions within the Shopify admin.

frontMatter.title: Account connection
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used for connecting or disconnecting a store to various accounts, like Facebook for the sales channel.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to let merchants connect or disconnect their store to their third-party accounts, like Facebook.

frontMatter.title: Button
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used primarily for actions like 'Add', 'Close', 'Cancel', or 'Save'. Plain buttons are used for less important actions.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Used most in the interface. Only use another style if a button requires more or less visual weight.

examples.title: Plain
examples.description: Use for less important or less commonly used actions since they’re less prominent. For example, plain buttons are used as actions in cards.

examples.title: Tertiary
examples.description: Use for tertiary actions. Can be paired with any other button style to create visual variation.

examples.title: Plain critical
examples.description: Use for actions that will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from. Since they’re less prominent, use for less important or less commonly used critical actions. For example, plain buttons are used as actions in cards.

examples.title: Primary
examples.description: Use to highlight the most important actions in any experience. Don’t use more than one primary button in a section or screen to avoid overwhelming merchants.

examples.title: Primary critical
examples.description: Use when the action will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from. Critical buttons should trigger a confirmation dialog before the action is completed. Be thoughtful about using critical buttons because they can feel stressful for merchants.

examples.title: Large
examples.description: Use for the main call to action in empty states or for calls to action shown with large illustrations.

examples.title: Full-width
examples.description: Use for buttons placed in a narrow column (especially when stacking multiple buttons) or for creating a set of buttons of equal width. Full-width buttons should rarely exceed 320 px wide.

examples.title: Text-aligned
examples.description: Use for plain or monochrome buttons that could have a long length and should be aligned when they potentially overflow onto the next line.

examples.title: Pressed
examples.description: Buttons are sometimes used as a toggle for other parts of the user interface.

examples.title: Plain disclosure
examples.description: Use to indicate that more content can be disclosed on click, like text in a collapsible.

examples.title: Right-aligned disclosure
examples.description: When working with `fullWidth + textAlign="left"`, the `disclosure` will align itself to the far right.

examples.title: Select disclosure
examples.description: Use to indicate that multiple options are available from this control, similar to a `<select />` HTML element.

examples.title: Split
examples.description: Use when there is only one primary action but other related actions can be taken.

examples.title: Disabled state
examples.description: Use for actions that aren’t currently available. The surrounding interface should make it clear why the button is disabled and what needs to be done to enable it.

examples.title: Loading state
examples.description: Use when a button has been pressed and the associated action is in progress.

frontMatter.title: Button group
frontMatter.shortDescription: Displays multiple related actions stacked or in a horizontal row for arrangement and spacing.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when you have multiple buttons to space them out evenly.

examples.title: With segmented buttons
examples.description: Use to emphasize several buttons as a thematically-related set among other controls.

examples.title: Pressed with segmented buttons
examples.description: Pressed buttons can be used in combination to create a toggle for other parts of the user interface.

frontMatter.title: Page actions
frontMatter.shortDescription: Allows merchants to take key actions at the bottom of specific pages in the interface.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Used on a resource page (such as an individual order or product page) to let merchants take key actions at the bottom of the page. Usually, the primary action is Save and the secondary action is Delete.

examples.title: Primary action only
examples.description: Not all page actions require a secondary action.

examples.title: With custom primary action
examples.description: Use to create a custom primary action.

examples.title: With custom secondary action
examples.description: Use to create a custom secondary action.

frontMatter.title: Deprecated
frontMatter.shortDescription: Deprecated components will be removed in future major versions of Polaris. They should be avoided and will show warnings.

frontMatter.title: Caption
frontMatter.shortDescription: Caption text is smaller than the recommended size for general reading. Used in graphs, timestamps, or as secondary text.

frontMatter.title: Display text
frontMatter.shortDescription: Display styles make a bold visual statement. Used for visual storytelling, marketing content, or capturing attention.

frontMatter.title: Heading
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used as the titles of each major section of a page in the interface, like in card components.

frontMatter.title: Legacy card
frontMatter.shortDescription: Legacy version of the Card component. Used to group similar concepts and tasks together for easier scanning and reading.
keywords: card with call to action in the footer
card with call to action in the heading
card with call to action in a section
card with button in the footer
card with button in the heading

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use when you have a simple message to communicate to merchants that doesn’t require any secondary steps.

examples.title: With header actions
examples.description: Use for less important card actions, or actions merchants may do before reviewing the contents of the card. For example, merchants may want to add items to a card containing a long list, or enter a customer’s new address.

examples.title: With footer actions
examples.description: Use footer actions for a card’s most important actions, or actions merchants should do after reviewing the contents of the card. For example, merchants should review the contents of a shipment before an important action like adding tracking information. Footer actions can be left or right aligned with the `footerActionAlignment` prop.

examples.title: With multiple footer actions
examples.description: When multiple secondary footer actions are provided, they will render in an action list popover activated by a disclosure button. The disclosure button text can be customized with the `secondaryFooterActionsDisclosureText` prop.

examples.title: With custom footer actions
examples.description: Use to present actionable content that is optional or not the primary purpose of the page.

examples.title: With destructive footer action
examples.description: Use when a card action will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from.

examples.title: With multiple sections
examples.description: Use when you have two related but distinct pieces of information to communicate to merchants. Multiple sections can help break up complicated concepts to make them easier to scan and understand.

examples.title: With multiple titled sections
examples.description: Use when you have two related but distinct pieces of information to communicate to merchants that are complex enough to require a title to introduce them.

examples.title: With sections and actions
examples.description: Use when your card section has actions that apply only to that section.

examples.title: With subsection
examples.description: Use when your card sections need further categorization.

examples.title: With destructive action
examples.description: Use when a card action applies only to one section and will delete merchant data or be otherwise difficult to recover from.

examples.title: With a subdued section
examples.description: Use to indicate when one of the sections in your card contains inactive or disabled content.

examples.title: With subdued for secondary content
examples.description: Use for content that you want to deprioritize. Subdued cards don’t stand out as much as cards with white backgrounds so don’t use them for information or actions that are critical to merchants.

examples.title: With separate header
examples.description: Use to be able to use custom React elements as header content.

examples.title: With custom React Node title
examples.description: Use to render custom content such as icons, links, or buttons in a card section’s header.

examples.title: With all elements
examples.description: Use as a broad example that includes most props available to card.

examples.title: With flushed sections
examples.description: Use when you need further control over the spacing of your card sections.

frontMatter.title: Legacy filters
frontMatter.shortDescription: Legacy version of the Filters component. Used to filter the items of a list or table.

frontMatter.title: Legacy stack
frontMatter.shortDescription: Legacy version of the Stack component. Used for layout of a horizontal row of components or vertical centering.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to quickly lay out a horizontal row of components and maintain their relative sizes. On small screens, children rows wrap down to additional rows as needed.

examples.title: Non-wrapping
examples.description: Use to create a stack where the children will not wrap to new rows on small screens. As noted above, the wrap option defaults to true. This means you must explicitly set it to false to turn it off.

examples.title: Spacing
examples.description: Use to control spacing of items in a stack in standard increments. Use tight for less spacing, loose for more spacing, or none to remove normal spacing altogether.

examples.title: Vertical centering
examples.description: Use to vertically center a set of items that have different heights.

examples.title: Fill available space proportionally
examples.description: Use to have the stack’s items fill the horizontal space in the container but maintain their relative proportions.

examples.title: Where items fill space evenly
examples.description: Use to have the stack’s items fill the horizontal space in the container and be equal widths, regardless of their content.

examples.title: Where a single item fills the remaining space
examples.description: Use for aligning buttons or secondary content to the right edge of another element, allowing it to wrap below on small screens.

frontMatter.title: Legacy tabs
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to alternate among related views within the same context.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use for most cases, especially when the number of tabs may be more than three.

examples.title: Fitted
examples.description: Use when tabs contain a few (2 or 3) items within a narrow column.

examples.title: With badge content
examples.description: Use to inform a piece of information about the tabs.

examples.title: With custom disclosure
examples.description: Use to provide information about the popover contents

frontMatter.title: Setting toggle
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to control a feature or option that can be turned on or off.

examples.title: With primitive components
examples.description: Use to allow merchants to toggle a setting that has an on or off state. Display the name of the setting and provide a description so merchants have the context needed to decide whether or not to enable the setting. This pattern is built using the layout and typography components, instead of the deprecated `SettingToggle` component.

examples.title: With deprecated component
examples.description: The setting toggle component is deprecated. The "With primitive components" example is the recommended way to build the setting toggle pattern.

frontMatter.title: Sheet
frontMatter.shortDescription: A large container providing actions and information contextual to the page without interrupting flow like a modal.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use as the default option for a sheet.

examples.title: With searchable listbox
examples.description: Use to help merchants browse, filter, and choose from a list of options.

frontMatter.title: Subheading
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used for the title of any sub-sections in top-level page sections.

frontMatter.title: Text container
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to wrap text elements like paragraphs, headings, and lists for vertical spacing.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use this component for default vertical spacing.

examples.title: Tight
examples.description: Use the tight spacing option to relate content topics to each other.

examples.title: Loose
examples.description: Use the loose spacing option to separate concepts that are independent of each other.

frontMatter.title: Text style
frontMatter.shortDescription: Enhances text with additional visual meaning, like using subdued text to de-emphasize it.

frontMatter.title: Visually hidden
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used when an element needs to be available to assistive technology but otherwise hidden.
keywords: hidden but available for screen readers

frontMatter.title: Feedback indicators
frontMatter.shortDescription: Inform merchants about the status of a process, provide feedback, or indicate progress.

frontMatter.title: Badge
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to inform merchants of the tone of an object or an action taken.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to give a non-critical tone update on a piece of information or action.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use in layouts with minimal space, like inside of an `IndexTable` cell.

examples.title: Informational
examples.description: Use to call out an object or action as having an important attribute. For example, marking an option as “Recommended” or marking a theme as “Published”.

examples.title: Success
examples.description: Use to indicate a successful, completed, or desirable state when it’s important to provide positive reinforcement to merchants. For example, when merchants successfully dispute a chargeback, a success badge shows that says “Funds recovered”.

examples.title: Attention
examples.description: Use when something requires merchants’ attention but the issue isn’t critical. For example, this badge would show next to an order that needs to be reviewed by merchants.

examples.title: Warning
examples.description: Use for warnings and time-sensitive issues that require merchants’ attention and potential action. Warning events are often reversible. Keep in mind that seeing this badge can feel stressful for merchants so it should only be used when absolutely necessary.

examples.title: Critical
examples.description: Use for critical and irreversible issues that require merchants’ attention and potential action. Keep in mind that seeing this badge can feel stressful for merchants so it should only be used when absolutely necessary.

examples.title: Incomplete
examples.description: Use to indicate when a given task has not yet been completed. For example, when merchants haven’t fulfilled an order.

examples.title: Partially complete
examples.description: Use to indicate when a given task has been partially completed. For example, when merchants have partially fulfilled an order.

examples.title: Complete
examples.description: Use to indicate when a given task has been completed. For example, when merchants have fulfilled an order.

examples.title: With toneAndProgressLabelOverride
examples.description: Use when the tone and progress accessibilityLabels are not appropriate to a given context.

frontMatter.title: Banner
frontMatter.shortDescription: Informs merchants about important changes or persistent conditions in a prominent way.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to convey general information or actions that aren’t critical. For example, you might show a banner that asks for merchant feedback. Default banners contain lower priority information and should always be dismissible.

examples.title: Dismissible
examples.description: Make all banners dismissible, unless they contain critical information or an important action that merchants are required to take.

examples.title: With footer call-to-action
examples.description: Use when you want merchants to take an action after reading the banner.

examples.title: Informational
examples.description: Use to update merchants about a change or give them advice.

examples.title: Success
examples.description: Default to using toasts for success messages, unless the feedback is delayed, persistent, or has a call to action. Include next steps if applicable.

examples.title: Warning
examples.description: Use to display information that needs attention or that merchants need to take action on. Seeing these banners can be stressful for merchants so be cautious about using them.

examples.title: Critical
examples.description: Use to communicate problems that have to be resolved immediately for merchants to complete a task. For example, you will show this banner for orders with high fraud risk. Seeing these banners can be stressful for merchants so be cautious about using them.

examples.title: In a modal
examples.description: Banners inside of modals render with less spacing and a pared-back design to fit within a content context.

examples.title: With focus
examples.description: Banner can programmatically receive focus. Use this functionality to draw the merchant’s attention to the banner.

examples.title: In a card
examples.description: Banners inside of cards render with less spacing and a pared-back design to fit within a content context.

frontMatter.title: Exception list
frontMatter.shortDescription: Helps merchants notice important, standout information that adds extra context to a task.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use icons to add clarity or assist in visualizing the meaning

frontMatter.title: Loading
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to indicate to merchants that a page is loading or an upload is processing.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to indicate that the page is loading.

frontMatter.title: Progress bar
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to visually represent the completion of a task or operation.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use this component to visually represent the completion of a task or operation.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use the size option when you need to increase or decrease the visual weight of the progress bar.

examples.title: Colored
examples.description: Use the color option when you need to blend the progress bar in a context that calls for it, such as a progress toward success or where it’s the primary focus.

examples.title: Non-animated
examples.description: Use the animated prop when you want to show a static progress bar.

frontMatter.title: Skeleton body text
frontMatter.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of content before it appears, improving perceived load times.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use this component to represent a block of content being loaded. For example, you could use it to represent an entire product description card on the product page.

examples.title: Single line content
examples.description: Use this component to represent a short, single line of text, like a timestamp.

frontMatter.title: Skeleton display text
frontMatter.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of content before it appears, improving perceived load times.

examples.title: Medium and large
examples.description: Use this component to represent medium and large display text such as large metrics on the reports list page, or for page titles.

examples.title: Extra large
examples.description: Use this component to represent extra large display text.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use this component to represent small display text such as content headings.

frontMatter.title: Skeleton page
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used with other skeleton loading components to provide a low fidelity representation of the UI before content appears.

examples.title: With dynamic content
examples.description: Use this component to compose a loading version of a page where the page title and header content are dynamic, meaning, the content changes.

examples.title: With static content
examples.description: Use this component to compose a loading version of a page where the page title and header content are known and stay the same.

frontMatter.title: Skeleton tabs
frontMatter.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of content before it appears, improving perceived load times.

frontMatter.title: Skeleton thumbnail
frontMatter.shortDescription: Provides a low fidelity representation of an image before it appears, improving perceived load times.

examples.title: Medium
examples.description: Use this component to represent medium thumbnails.

examples.title: Large
examples.description: Use this component to represent large thumbnails.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use this component to represent small thumbnails.

examples.title: Extra small
examples.description: Use this component to represent extra small thumbnails.

frontMatter.title: Spinner
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to notify merchants that their action is being processed. Used for content that can’t be represented with skeleton loading components.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to notify merchants that their requested action is being processed.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Smaller than the default spinner.

examples.title: With focus management
examples.description: Use to direct the focus state from the control to the spinner, to the content.

frontMatter.title: Toast
frontMatter.shortDescription: A non-disruptive message that provides quick feedback on the outcome of an action.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to convey general confirmation or actions that aren’t critical. For example, you might show a toast message to inform the merchant that their recent action was successful.

examples.title: Multiple messages
examples.description: Use multiple toast messages to inform the merchant about distinct actions.

examples.title: With custom duration
examples.description: Use to shorten or lengthen the default duration of 5000 milliseconds.

examples.title: With action
examples.description: Use when a merchant has the ability to act on the message. For example, to undo a change or retry an action.

examples.title: Error
examples.description: Although error toast is still available and used in the system, we discourage its use. Reserve it for errors not caused by merchants, like a connection issue. Error toast should convey what went wrong in plain language and should not go over 3 words. For all other error message types, follow the [error message guidelines](https://polaris.shopify.com/patterns/error-messages).

frontMatter.title: Images and icons
frontMatter.shortDescription: Represent visual content, such as avatars and thumbnails for images or video.

frontMatter.title: Avatar
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to show a thumbnail representation of an individual or business in the interface.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to present an avatar for a merchant, customer, or business.

examples.title: Initials
examples.description: Use to present an avatar with initials for a merchant, customer, or business.

examples.title: Extra small
examples.description: Use to present an avatar in a condensed layout, such as a data table cell or an action list item.

frontMatter.title: Icon
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to visually communicate core parts of the product and available actions, acting as wayfinding tools.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to visually communicate core parts of the product and available actions.

examples.title: Colored
examples.description: Apply a color to the icon.

examples.title: With custom SVG
examples.description: Specify an SVG as a string to render it in an image tag, instead of an inline SVG to prevent script injection.

examples.title: With custom SVG and color
examples.description: When using changing color of an svg and it uses currentColor, the white color is applied.

frontMatter.title: Keyboard key
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to educate merchants about keyboard shortcuts.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to list a related set of keyboard shortcuts.

frontMatter.title: Thumbnail
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used as a visual anchor and identifier for an object, along with text to provide context.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use as the default size.

examples.title: Extra small
examples.description: Use to present a thumbnail in a condensed layout, such as a data table cell or an action list item.

examples.title: Small
examples.description: Use when the default size is too large for the layout, or when the thumbnail has less importance.

examples.title: Large
examples.description: Use when a thumbnail is a major focal point. Avoid this size in lists of like items.

examples.title: With component source
examples.description: Use to render an icon inside of thumbnail.

frontMatter.title: Video thumbnail
frontMatter.shortDescription: A clickable placeholder image that opens a video player within a modal or full screen when clicked.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use as a play button for a video player within a media card.

examples.title: With progress
examples.description: Use to indicate the video’s play progress in relation to its duration.

frontMatter.title: Layout and structure
frontMatter.shortDescription: The arrangement of elements on a page that helps merchants understand and find information to complete their goals.

frontMatter.title: Bleed
frontMatter.shortDescription: Applies negative margin to a layout, extending it to the edge of the screen on small screens.

examples.title: Horizontal
examples.description: Content will bleed horizontally into the surrounding layout using the `marginInline` prop.

examples.title: Vertical
examples.description: Content will bleed vertically into the surrounding layout using the `marginBlock` prop.

examples.title: Specific direction
examples.description: Negative margins can be added in a specific direction using the [Space tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/space).

examples.title: Gap
examples.description: Control the vertical space between children using the `gap` prop.

examples.title: Align
examples.description: Control the vertical alignment of children using the `align` prop.

examples.title: Inline align
examples.description: Control the horizontal alignment of children using the `inlineAlign` prop.

examples.title: Color
examples.description: Background color of box and text color inside a box can be adjusted using the [Color tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/color).

examples.title: Border width
examples.description: Border width can be adjusted using the [Border tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/border), and a subset of tokens allows different types of border.

examples.title: Border radius
examples.description: Border radius can be adjusted using the [Border tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/border).

examples.title: Padding
examples.description: Padding can be added to either all sides, left, right, top, and bottom, using the [Space tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/space). The `padding` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Shadow
examples.description: Shadow can be applied using the [Shadow tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/shadow).

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to let merchants know about a feature or opportunity where there is a clear, single action they need to take to move to the next step.

examples.title: With secondary action
examples.description: Use to let merchants know about a feature or opportunity where there are two distinct actions they can take on the information.

examples.title: Dismissable
examples.description: Make all callout cards dismissible so merchants can get rid of cards about features they’re not interested in.

frontMatter.title: Card
frontMatter.shortDescription: Used to group similar concepts and tasks together for easier scanning and reading.
keywords: card with call to action in the footer
card with call to action in the heading
card with call to action in a section
card with button in the footer
card with button in the heading

examples.title: Default
examples.description: By default, cards have an 8px border radius and uses `--p-color-bg-surface` as the background and `--p-shadow-300` as the shadow. There is padding of `space-5` (20px) around children and `space-4` (16px) for small screens.

examples.title: With subdued background
examples.description: Use for content that you want to deprioritize. Subdued cards don’t stand out as much as cards with white backgrounds so don’t use them for information or actions that are critical to merchants.

examples.title: With varying padding
examples.description: Use the `padding` property to adjust the spacing within a card. You can also specify spacing values at different breakpoints.

examples.title: Rounded corners
examples.description: Use the `padding` property to adjust the spacing of content within a card. The `padding` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Color
examples.description: Divider border color can be adjusted using the [Color tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/color).

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to explain a single feature before merchants have used it.

examples.title: With subdued footer context
examples.description: Use to provide additional but non-critical context for a new product or feature. Can also be used to include a subdued call to action for secondary or tertiary actions.

frontMatter.title: Form layout
frontMatter.shortDescription: Manages the layout of all forms and fields within it. Used for the layout of new forms and managing the layout of all forms.

examples.title: Default
examples.description: Use to stack form fields vertically, which makes them easier to scan and complete.

examples.title: Field group
examples.description: Use field groups to arrange multiple fields in a row. Works best for familiar layouts such as a row of city, state, and zip code fields. Use caution when arranging unrelated fields next to each other as this makes fields easier to miss. Field groups will wrap automatically on smaller screens.

examples.title: Condensed field group
examples.description: For very short inputs, the width of the inputs may be reduced in order to fit more fields in the row.

examples.title: Two column
examples.description: Use to create a two column layout that wraps at a breakpoint and aligns to a twelve column grid.

examples.title: Two-thirds and one-third column
examples.description: Use to create a two-thirds, one-third column layout that wraps at a breakpoint and aligns to a twelve column grid.

examples.title: Three one-third column
examples.description: Use to create a three column layout that wrap at a breakpoint and aligns to a twelve column grid.

examples.title: Custom layout
examples.description: Use to create a layout that can be customized at specific breakpoints.

examples.title: Gap
examples.description: Use the `gap` prop to set the amount of space between columns. The `gap` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Column width
examples.description: The `columns` property accepts CSS column shorthand syntax, or an array of strings mapping to common widths in the admin such as `oneThird`, `oneHalf`, and `twoThirds`. For responsive columns, use the same syntax passed into an object with the breakpoints.

examples.title: Number of columns
examples.description: Control the number of columns using the `columns` prop. Column numbers can be responsively set using the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Non-wrapping
examples.description: The default wrapping behavior of children can be overridden using the `wrap` prop.

examples.title: Gap
examples.description: Control the horizontal and vertical space between children using the `gap` prop. The `gap` prop supports responsive spacing with the [Breakpoints tokens](https://polaris.shopify.com/tokens/breakpoints).

examples.title: Block align
examples.description: Control the vertical alignment of children using the `blockAlign` prop.

examples.title: Align
examples.description: Control the horizontal alignment of children using the `align` prop.

frontMatter.title: Layout
frontMatter.shortDescription: A structural component used to group other components. Creates consistent spacing and helps layout stack and scale responsively.

examples.title: One-column
examples.description: Use to have a single section on its own in a full-width container. Use for simple pages and as a container for banners and other full-width content.

examples.title: Two columns with primary and secondary widths
examples.description: Use to follow a normal section with a secondary section to create a 2/3 + 1/3 layout on detail pages (such as individual product or order pages). Can also be used on any page that needs to structure a lot of content. This layout stacks the columns on small screens.

examples.title: Two columns with equal width
examples.description: Use to create a ½ + ½ layout. Can be used to display content of equal importance. This layout will stack the columns on small screens.

examples.title: Three columns with equal width
examples.description: Use to create a ⅓ + ⅓ + ⅓ layout. Can be used to display content of equal importance. This layout will stack the columns on small screens.

examples.title: Annotated
examples.description: Use for settings pages. When settings are grouped thematically in annotated sections, the title and description on each section helps merchants quickly find the setting they’re looking for.

examples.title: Annotated with sections
examples.description: Use for settings pages. When settings are grouped thematically in annotated sections, the title and description on each section helps merchants quickly find the setting they’re looking for.

examples.title: Annotated with Banner at the top
examples.description: Use for settings pages that need a banner or other content at the top.

frontMatter.title: Media card
frontMatter.shortDescription: Provides a container for introductory or highlight information. Often used in a grid to present related content.

examples.title: Default
